Author: dredmorbius
Content:
For those interested in the Breyer reference:

Breyer, The Uneasy Case for Copyright: A Study of Copyright in Books, Photocopies, and Computer Programs, 84 Harv. L. Rev. 281 (1970)

http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?handle=hein.journals/u...

I've been unable to turn up a copy of the article
Created:
and even references to citations from Google Scholar appear to be 404.

It's also apparently one of the most-cited articles on copyright law (not entirely surprising as its author sits on the Supreme Court). One such citation is an amicus brief with a profoundly interesting set of signatories (many of whom I wouldn't expect to agree on whether or not water is wet) in Eldred v. Ashcroft
column12:
the Supreme Court case argued by Lawrence Lessig over copyright extension:

http://www.brookings.edu/~/media/research/files/reports/2002..."

Author: dredmorbius
Content:
As I said, Justice Breyer's paper was quite interesting. It turns out that, at least at the time he wrote it, textbooks (I don't recall if he distinguished between collegiate and primary/secondary, more later), and technical books, constituted a very large portion of the publishing market and a disproportionate portion of the profits.

In the primary/secondary school market, you have a number of issues at play. There's the separation of buyer (a school district or state board official usually) and the payer (generally taxpayers at large, sometimes students. This creates a similar severing of the normal roles of decisionmaker and payor to that found in healthcare (a patient requests service, the insurance carrier pays for it) or the military (a purchasing officer approves the purchase, taxpayers pay). There's also a separation between the agent and _user_, which also shows up in a number of other contexts (corporate purchasing would be a typical example).

The other is that there are a number of markets which have an undue influence on the broader textbook industry. Large states such as California, Texas, and New York represent millions of students, but of these, Texas makes statewide purchasing decisions on what books to buy. The reason the building from which Lee Harvey Oswald shot JFK was called the Texas school book depository is because it was the Texas School Book Depository, leased at the time by a company which did a large part of the order fulfillment for the state of Texas. So purchase decisions by Texas influence the economics of publishing to the extent of governing what books may be available elsewhere. The politicization of this in particular as regards creationists trying to beat down evolution has impacts throughout the United States.

Author: lelandbatey
Content: How is it that OSM is of higher quality than Google maps, when Google apparently spends $1 billion+ a year maintaining their maps? I'm not doubting the claim, just curious.
